titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Rentschler's Studio photograph collection, 1889-1969
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Christopher Leonard

did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan photographic studio. Collection includes selected copy prints, and glass and film negatives relating to University of Michigan athletics, both photos of individual athletes and of team groupings; also photos of various faculty and University administrators and log books of photos.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was given to the library in 1983 by Lois Rentschler (Donor No. 6950) and Herbert Pfabe, Sr (Donor No. 5377)

accruals.p: No further additions to the collection expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction except for the 11 x 14 glass negatives of the football team photos which have been scanned and are available through the Bentley Library Image Bank.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Rentschler's Studio photograph collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Born in Ann Arbor in 1868, J. Fred Rentschler became the city's most respected portrait photographer. After serving as an apprentice at the Gibson studios, Rentschler opened his own studio in 1890. He operated Rentschler's Studios until his death in 1940. At that time, his son Edwin D. Rentschler took over the business. When Edwin died in 1971, the studio soon ceased operation under the Rentschler name.

scopecontent.p: The Rentschler Studios collection is made up of nearly 625 negatives and 275 copy prints. It comprises five linear feet and is stored in seven boxes, four large and three small. The collection also includes the studio's log books of photos. The photographs span the years from 1889 to 1969. Although the Rentschlers operated a private studio, over two-thirds of the portraits are of persons directly affiliated with the University of Michigan. The two largest categories of portraits are: 1) faculty and administrators and 2) athletes, teams, and coaches. There are also portraits of students, clergy, businessmen, city officials, and others.

The collection is divided into three series, Negatives, Prints, and Log Books. Glass and film negatives comprise the vast majority of the collection and are arranged into four subseries: Numerical; Team Portraits; Miscellaneous; and Football Team Portraits, 1896-1942. The smaller series - Prints - is located in Box 4 and is arranged into two subseries: Athletics and Portraits.

The Negatives series, glass and film negatives, comprises the vast majority of the collection and are arranged into four subseries: Numerical; Team Portraits; Miscellaneous; and Football Team Portraits, 1896-1942.

The Numerical subseries of the Negatives series is stored in the first three boxes. The portraits in this subseries have been indexed by the subject's name. There are three indexes: athletes and coaches, faculty and administrators, and a third index for those individuals who do not fit into the first two categories.

Team Portraits include lengthy runs of the football, baseball, basketball, golf, gymnastics, track, and wrestling teams for the years 1948-1969. Only football team portraits are extensive before World War II. However, as these early football team portraits from 1896-1942 are outsize glass negatives, they are stored separately in the Football Team Portraits, 1896-1942 subseries in Boxes 5 to 7.

The Miscellaneous Negatives subseries consists of two negative boxes, containing approximately eighty negatives of miscellaneous unindexed portraits. All portraits in this subseries are from the 1950s and 1960s.

odd.p: (mostly 5x7 glass negatives, with a few 8x10 glass negatives)
(see also outsize glass negatives in boxes 5-7 for team photos, 1898-1942)
(original negatives and some copy negatives, some identified by last name)

scopecontent.p: In the Prints series, the Athletics subseries generally duplicates the team portrait negatives. There are, however, five folders of senior portraits of football players for 1965-1969. A complete list of senior portraits follows the index of athletes and coaches.
The Portraits subseries of prints is comprised of two folders of portraits, many unidentified. Those which have been identified are indexed with the negatives.

odd.p: (8x10 team photos from Rentschler negatives unless otherwise stated)

scopecontent.p: The Log Books series, consists of two volumes of logs of the subjects of the studio's photo work and one address book. The first log book volume labeled "Faculty and Prominent People." Both log books are arranged alphabetically and include the name of the person and the negative number. The surviving negatives in the collection are only a small subset of the items recorded into log books. The address book includes and index and photos of All-Americans and football captains in addition to business and personal addresses. The indexes in this finding aid can be used in lieu of the indexes in these volumes.

descgrp.p: To help locate photographs quickly, the three following indexes have been prepared. They are: 1) Athletes and Coaches Index, 2) Faculty and Administrators Index and 3) Miscellaneous Index. The first two indices include only the names of persons who clearly fall into these categories. Therefore, if one is looking for a particular athlete or professor, it would be advisable to also consult the Miscellaneous Index. A negative number beside the name indicates the availability of a negative. The location is determined by the number. Numbers 05010-29999 are in Box 1, numbers 30000-57999 in Box 2, numbers 58000-84999 and U001-U010 in Box 3. If the word “print” follows the entry, the image is available on a print. These are located in Box 4 in the folder labeled “Portraits, identified, A-Z.”
